Like a shop-a-holic binging on credit cards, Zimbabwe's frantically digging itself deeper and deeper into debt.
The government tried to control this by declaring that it would set interest rates rather than letting them be set by the market.
Of course, the rates they set for their own debts were extremely low.
Markets are very powerful, and I think any government anywhere in the world that decides to go into battle against market forces tends to lose.
But while they're losing, the country goes downhill.
And this is exactly what we've experienced in Zimbabwe.
The downhill slide has affected every aspect of society.
Education rates are slipping.
Some four million people, or almost a third of the population, have fled Zimbabwe to try to find work abroad.
Life expectancy is now just 37 years, one of the lowest in Africa.
This June, the United Nations downgraded Zimbabwe from a developing country to a least developed nation, ranking it on par with some of the poorest places on the planet.
President Mugabe is 82 years old, but it's still unclear when he will step down.
Peter Kagwanja with the International Crisis Group in Pretoria, South Africa, says Mugabe is pitting potential successors against one another to extend his own time in power.

Kagwanja and many other analysts predict there won't be a solution to Zimbabwe's problems until Robert Mugabe leaves office.
The good news for Africa is that Mugabe is one of the last of the African big men, such as Mobuto Sese Seko of Zaire, Daniel Arap Moi in Kenya, Omar Bongo of Gabon, and Charles Taylor in Liberia.
